Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Origins of a Historical Understanding of the Universe

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Project Overview

This award supports doctoral dissertation research that explores the emergence of modern cosmology in the history of nineteenth century astronomy. The goal of the co-PI (the doctoral dissertation researcher) is to provide an account of how the universe was understood in western intellectual networks and popular culture during that period. In pursuing that goal, the co-PI will examine the ways in which the development of cosmology was an interdisciplinary process that strongly influenced nineteenth-century science and society. The development and social impact of this transformation will be explored through research in manuscript archives in the US, UK, and France.

Intellectual Merit

The emergence of modern cosmology remains unexplored and significantly under-researched. While addressing this gap, the co-PI will illuminate the relationship between Romantic philosophy, public culture, and the development of a historical understanding of the universe. He will also reveal significant methodological interplay between nineteenth-century astronomy, geology, and life sciences; for example, that they share similar problems and develop similar epistemological solutions. The co-PI is well positioned to engage in this research project. The PI (the co-PI's mentor) brings expertise in the history of nineteenth-century life sciences. The co-PI's credentials include a bachelor's degree in astronomy and astrophysics, and the doctoral dissertation committee includes an astrophysicist and historians of science.

Broader Impacts

In addition to presenting the results of this research in journal articles and at professional meetings, the co-PI hopes to develop the material into an undergraduate course and to publish the research as a book, written in an accessible style, for the general public and academics alike.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project outcomes report describes the co-PI's research findings as well as both completed and planned project products (e.g. presentations, papers, coursework, books, &c.). The co-PI's research was pursued and analyzed under the guidance of her academic advisor, the project PI. 

The Hubble Space Telescope and other modern instruments allow us to witness stunning moments of creation and evolution in the universe: the birth of stars, their changes over time, and often spectacular stellar deaths, not to mention a wide and astonishing variety of galaxies and other celestial bodies at different stages of development. We are able to study the universe's past, consider nearly unimaginable swaths of cosmic space, and contemplate vast epochs of its history on time scales of often millions or billions of years. This project researched and analyzed how such remarkable scientific feats became possible over the course of eighteenth- and nineteenth-century European and American history. How was it that astronomers came to realize that the universe was dynamic and historical — that stars, galaxies, and other celestial objects changed over periods of time many orders of magnitude longer than a single human observer's lifetime? 

The research revealed that these important scientific developments occurred in significant part due to a critical interdisciplinary connection: many theories of cosmic transformation were associated with theories of natural historical transformations, and vice versa. Thus, some of the earliest theorists of biological evolution — such as Erasmus Darwin — articulated their theories in the context of arguments about evolution as a more fundamental feature of the universe as a whole. This argument found an especially enthusiastic reception in the context of Romantic literature, particularly "popular science" publications intended for public consumption. Eighteenth- and nineteenth-century astronomical thinkers applied the methods of botanists, zoologists, and geologists to the study of cosmology to overcome the limitations of observation. At first glance, this seems like an astonishing idea. What could an insect, a shrub, or a mountain have to do with a star?

The answer is twofold. First, these seemingly disparate fields shared an essential problem. Their objects of study — stars, strata, and species — experienced many of their most significant changes in the distant past, and over periods of time too long to be observed in full. They all exhibited phenomena that were difficult to produce experimentally (just try making a full-size star in a laboratory!). In short, they all required scientific methods capable of dealing with observational and experimental limitations.  Natural historians of the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries had already developed a way of discerning processes that had not been directly observed in full, based on analogies with the life histories of plants and animals. Just as the collector of butterflies could arrange separate specimens of the same type on a pin board in order of development from egg, to larva, to pupa, to butterfly (i.e., the developmental trajectory of one species revealed by using different specimens captured at discrete moments in time), so too could the collector of observations of stars and nebulae arrange his "specimens" by order of progressive development, by placing similar objects next to one another in order based on certain observed principles of natural law (such as the action of gravity) until the full developmental trajectory was revealed. Knowledge of the dynamic trajectory of celestial objects, in turn, could be used to obtain likely knowledge of their past states: their history.
